text:
Hey everyone,

Not sure if this is the right channel, but I’ll try it anyway. There’s a lot of advice out there for freelancers about how you should _know your worth_ and price accordingly. As content creators, aside from working out what you need to charge to stay afloat from your side of the table, how can you _know your worth_ from the client’s perspective? If their content marketing system isn’t sophisticated enough (I’ve honestly never had a client that could do this), and if you’re helping them work towards a long-term payoff with their content marketing, how can you genuinely _know your worth_? How do you put a dollar figure on an abstract idea? Is there a way to do this other than simply comparing it to relevant salary data, etc.?

from the client’s perspective? If their content marketing system isn’t sophisticated enough (I’ve honestly never had a client that could do this), and if you’re helping them work towards a long-term payoff with their content marketing, how can you genuinely
? How do you put a dollar figure on an abstract idea? Is there a way to do this other than simply comparing it to relevant salary data, etc.?

text:
Hey Amelia! One of the ways I did it was agree on pay raises after achieving milestones within my control.

The key was working with someone who understood content is a longterm game and their patience is needed. For example, the YouTube channel at VEED (where I work) now drives 40K to 50K visitors and 175+ monthly conversions.

Before the channel started working we had to figure out what kind of content even got engagement on the platform. This was then followed by which type of engaging content drives the most business value to us (traffic back to the site).

It was a loooong discovery process to know how to drive quality traffic from our channel.

I think a lot of clients are misinformed because of inexperienced freelancers who overpromise and underdeliver on unrealistic expectations. They are promised results and told what they want to hear but never walked through the why, what and how of the execution of things.

Who knows, maybe it’s not so much about the money and more emotional. Maybe they have spent so much money on the wrong freelancers before they are anxious and stressed about their next investment in a freelancer.


P.S. Sometimes there are also people who don’t get this and need to go hire someone for low quality work so they finally understand why they need to pay more for quality.
